Legal_Issue: Whether traditional Chinese medicine qualifies as a cultural activity under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations for self-employed person status
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's experience in traditional Chinese medicine assessed as business activity, not cultural
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate eligibility under self-employed person class
Legal_Rule: Subsection 88(1) defines self-employed person; requires two one-year periods of self-employment in cultural activities typically related to arts
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied to visa officer's decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Applicant claimed eligibility under self-employed person category based on traditional Chinese medicine practice
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected: traditional Chinese medicine not considered a cultural activity under the regulations
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of applicant's work in traditional Chinese medicine, regulatory definition of cultural activities
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged visa officer's interpretation of 'cultural activity'
Legal_Rule_Source: Subsection 88(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Defendant_Response: Regulatory interpretation supports exclusion of therapeutic practices from cultural activities
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of professional experience, regulatory text
Remedy_Requested: Overturn of visa refusal and grant of permanent residency
Outcome: Application dismissed; decision to deny upheld
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial review under administrative law principles
Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residency under self-employed person class
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to meet definition of self-employed person in cultural activities
Applicable_Process: Administrative decision-making followed by judicial review
Governing_Rule: Subsection 88(1), IRPR â€“ definition of self-employed person and qualifying experience
